<HR NOSHADE ALIGN="LEFT" WIDTH="120">
<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>(1)</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Excluding
DC9 aircraft, the average age of Northwest-operated aircraft is 9.5&nbsp;years.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>(2)</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Financing
commitments available for use by the Company are in place for all of these aircraft.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>(3)</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>These
aircraft will be leased or subleased to and operated by Pinnacle Airlines. The Company has the option to finance these aircraft through long-term operating lease
commitments from the manufacturer; if the manufacturer chooses not to provide financing, the Company is not required to take delivery of the aircraft.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>(4)</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Excludes
aircraft directly leased by Mesaba from third party lessors.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>(5)</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Excludes
aircraft leased to charter carriers. </FONT></DD></DL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
Company's DC9 aircraft have considerable remaining technological life, based upon the cycle life (capacity for number of landings) expected by the manufacturer and other factors. The
Company also believes that these aircraft have significant economic value given the Company's route network, </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>15</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=1,SEQ=15,EFW="2130102",CP="NORTHWEST AIRLINES CORPORATION",DN="1",CHK=314113,FOLIO='15',FILE='DISK016:[04STP4.04STP1114]DI1114A.;7',USER='TCHAN',CD=';4-MAR-2004;00:57' -->
<A NAME="page_di1114_1_16"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>maintenance
programs and the lack of a commercially successful new 100-seat aircraft at this time. The Company estimates that its DC9 aircraft could fly on average more than nine
additional years beyond 2003 based upon the manufacturer's expected cycle life for such aircraft and the projected annual utilization by Northwest. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;See
"Item 8. Consolidated Financial Statements and Supplementary Data, Note&nbsp;4&#151;Leases" and "Note&nbsp;10&#151;Commitments" for further information related to
the Company's aircraft leases and commitments. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Airport Facilities  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Northwest leases the majority of its airport facilities. The lease terms cover periods up to 30&nbsp;years and contain provisions for periodic adjustment of
lease payments. At most airports that it serves, Northwest has entered into use agreements that provide for the non-exclusive use of runways, taxiways and other facilities. Landing fees
under these agreements normally are based on the number of landings and weight of the aircraft. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
certain cases, the Company has constructed a facility on leased land which reverts to the lessor upon expiration of the lease. These facilities include cargo buildings in Boston, Los
Angeles, New York (JFK), Seattle and Honolulu; support buildings at the Minneapolis/St. Paul International Airport; a line maintenance hangar in Seattle; and a two-bay DC10 hangar in
Detroit. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
Company was responsible for managing and supervising the design and construction of the $1.2&nbsp;billion passenger terminal at Detroit Metropolitan Wayne County Airport that was
completed in February&nbsp;2002. The new terminal offers 97 gates, 106 ticket-counter positions, 22 security check points, nearly 85 shops and restaurants, four WorldClubs, an
11,500-space parking facility, covered curbside drop-off areas and 18 luggage carousels. The terminal also offers international-to-domestic connections
within the same facility. A new hotel in the terminal was completed in December&nbsp;2002, and a two-bay 747 hangar was completed in October&nbsp;2003. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
late 2003, an additional $175&nbsp;million expansion began on Detroit Metropolitan Wayne County Airport's west concourse. The Company is responsible for managing and supervising the
design and construction of this new expansion project. The project includes additional narrow-body and regional gates on Concourses B and C, related apron expansion including hydrant
fueling, loading bridges and gate systems and additional moving walkways. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Minneapolis/St.
Paul International Airport is undergoing a $2.7&nbsp;billion construction program that began in 1998. The major components completed include a 50% increase in vehicle
parking as well as an additional 15 mainline jet gates and 30 commuter gates. A new north/south runway, automated people movers and improvement of existing runways are scheduled to be completed in
phases through 2010. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
Memphis-Shelby County Airport Authority has undertaken a $400&nbsp;million airport renovation and expansion project. The airfield portion of the program provides nearly
$300&nbsp;million in airfield improvements, including a new 13,000-foot runway, which opened in late 2000. The majority of the $60&nbsp;million terminal renovation was completed in
2000, including the redesign of eight gates to accommodate Northwest regional jet service, 15 additional regional jet gates, a new WorldClub
and 11 new ticket counter positions. This program also includes $40&nbsp;million in future vehicle parking expansion and roadwork modifications. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Other Property and Equipment  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Northwest's primary offices are located at or near the Minneapolis/St. Paul International Airport. The Company owns a 160-acre site east of the
airport where the Company's corporate offices are located. Additional owned buildings include reservations centers in Baltimore, Tampa and Chisholm, </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>16</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=2,SEQ=16,EFW="2130102",CP="NORTHWEST AIRLINES CORPORATION",DN="1",CHK=641142,FOLIO='16',FILE='DISK016:[04STP4.04STP1114]DI1114A.;7',USER='TCHAN',CD=';4-MAR-2004;00:57' -->
<A NAME="page_di1114_1_17"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Minnesota,
and a data processing center in Eagan, Minnesota. The Company owns property in Tokyo, including a 1.3-acre site in downtown Tokyo and a 33-acre land parcel,
512-room hotel and flight kitchen located near Tokyo's Narita International Airport. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
Company leases reservations centers in or near Minneapolis/St. Paul and Seattle. Maintenance bases under operating leases are located in Minneapolis/St. Paul and Duluth, Minnesota.
As of December&nbsp;31, 2003, the Company operated 26 city ticket offices in North America. One of these city ticket offices was subsequently closed in January&nbsp;2004 and the Company announced
in February&nbsp;2004 that it will be closing all of its remaining North America city ticket offices by March&nbsp;2004. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
2003, the Company closed its Detroit area reservations center and city ticket offices located in Livonia, Michigan. The Company owns the building and land formerly used as the
reservations center and has entered into a purchase agreement to sell the property. The prospective buyer can terminate the agreement before the end of the inspection period. Call center activity
performed at the Detroit facility was transferred to the Company's facilities in Baltimore, Chisholm, Minneapolis, Seattle and Tampa. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Item 3. LEGAL PROCEEDINGS  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Chase v. Northwest Airlines and Airline Reporting Corporation</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2> (U.S. D.C. Eastern District of Michigan, Civ. Action
No.&nbsp;96-74711).&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Northwest is a defendant in an antitrust class action filed in U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Michigan in October&nbsp;1996. The
action purports to be brought on behalf of a class defined as all persons who purchased tickets on certain routes into
Northwest's hubs at Detroit, Minneapolis/St. Paul and Memphis from October&nbsp;11, 1992 to the present. The complaint alleges that Northwest's imposition of restrictions prohibiting the sale of
"hidden city" tickets constitutes monopolization in violation of the Sherman Act. The complaint seeks injunctive relief, unspecified damages for the class, and costs and attorneys' fees. The attorneys
for the plaintiff in </FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>Chase</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2> have also filed three additional class actions in the same court against other airlines and Northwest with parallel
allegations similar to those in </FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>Chase</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>, including allegations that the defendant airlines conspired to deter hidden city ticketing. These cases are: </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><I>Keystone Business Machines,
&nbsp;Inc. v. U.S. Airways and Northwest Airlines</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2> (U.S. D.C. Eastern District of Michigan, Civ. Action
No.&nbsp;99-72474)</FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>, BLT Contracting,&nbsp;Inc. v. U.S. Airways, Northwest Airlines and the Airline Reporting Corporation</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2> (U.S. D.C.
Eastern District of Michigan, Civ. Action No.&nbsp;99-72988)</FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>,</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2> and </FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>Volk and Nitrogenous Industries Corp. v. U.S.
Airways, Northwest Airlines, Delta Air Lines, and the Airline Reporting Corporation</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2> (U.S. D.C. Eastern District of Michigan, Civ. Action
No.&nbsp;99-72987)</FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2> All have been assigned to the Judge in the </FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>Chase</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2> case. Northwest
believes these cases are without merit and intends to defend against them. In November&nbsp;2000, the plaintiffs filed their class certification motion and defendants filed their summary judgment
motion. On May&nbsp;16, 2002, the Court entered an Order granting plaintiffs' motion for class certification and denying defendants' motion for summary judgment. The Court has not yet set a trial
date. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Midwestern Machinery Co.,&nbsp;Inc. v. Northwest Airlines,&nbsp;Inc.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;(U.S. D.C. District of Minnesota, Civ. Action
No.&nbsp;97-1438). In June&nbsp;1997, Midwestern Machinery Co. and several individuals filed an antitrust class action against Northwest in the U.S. District Court for Minnesota. The
complaint alleges that Northwest's acquisition of Republic Airlines in 1986 resulted in a substantial reduction in competition in violation of Section&nbsp;7 of the Clayton Act. Northwest believes
the lawsuit to be without merit and intends to defend against the claim. In February&nbsp;2001, the Court granted the plaintiff's motion for class certification. On February&nbsp;5, 2003, the
Court entered an Order granting Northwest's motion for summary judgment and dismissing the case. The plaintiff's appeal of the Court's Order granting summary judgment is pending. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Hall v. United Air Lines, et al.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;(U.S. D.C. Eastern District of North Carolina, Civ. Action No.&nbsp;7-00
CV-123-BR(1)). In October&nbsp;1999, a purported class action was filed in State Court in North Carolina </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>17</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=3,SEQ=17,EFW="2130102",CP="NORTHWEST AIRLINES CORPORATION",DN="1",CHK=958919,FOLIO='17',FILE='DISK016:[04STP4.04STP1114]DI1114A.;7',USER='TCHAN',CD=';4-MAR-2004;00:57' -->
<A NAME="page_di1114_1_18"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>by
a North Carolina travel agent, on behalf of herself and similarly situated North Carolina travel agents, challenging actions by most major airlines, including Northwest, to reduce travel agent base
commissions from 8&nbsp;percent to 5&nbsp;percent and alleging several state law theories of liability, including conspiracy. In June&nbsp;2000, the plaintiff filed a voluntary dismissal and
then filed a new case in federal court. The new case is a class action, now on behalf of a nation-wide class of travel agents, alleging an unlawful agreement among airlines to reduce
commissions in violation of the Sherman Act, and is based on the same factual allegations. On November&nbsp;13, 2001, the court granted the plaintiffs' motion to amend the complaint to include
allegations that other commission reductions in 1997 and 1998 were the result of unlawful agreements among the airline defendants in violation of the Sherman Act. The complaint was subsequently
amended again to allege that commission reductions in March&nbsp;2002 were also the result of an unlawful agreement among the airline defendants. Northwest believes the case to be without merit and
intends to defend against the claim. On September&nbsp;17, 2002, the Court entered an Order granting plaintiffs' motion for class certification. On October&nbsp;30, 2003, the Court granted the
Defendants' motion for summary judgment. The plaintiffs' appeal of the Court's Order granting summary judgment is pending. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;McCoy-Johnson v. Northwest Airlines</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2> (U.S. D.C. Western District of Tennessee, Civ. Action
No.&nbsp;2-99-CV-2994GV).&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In November&nbsp;1999, a purported class action was filed against Northwest by a Northwest passenger in federal court
alleging violations of Section&nbsp;2 of the Sherman Act. The plaintiff alleges that Northwest has monopolized or attempted to monopolize air transportation on certain routes into and out of its
three domestic hubs through a variety of exclusionary practices. The plaintiff purports to sue on behalf of all similarly situated passengers who purchased tickets on Northwest for travel on certain
routes into or out of its three hubs since at least as early as April&nbsp;1995. In March&nbsp;2001, a second case, </FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>Rodney v. Northwest Airlines</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>
(U.S. D.C. Western District of Tennessee, Civ. Action No.&nbsp;01-2167GV), was filed in the same court as a related case by the same counsel. The allegations in the </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><I>Rodney</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2> case are substantially the
same as those in the </FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>McCoy-Johnson</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2> case. In July&nbsp;2001, the
lawyers representing the plaintiffs in </FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>McCoy-Johnson</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2> and </FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>Rodney</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>filed another companion lawsuit, </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><I>Sax v. Northwest</I></FONT><FONT
SIZE=2> (U.S.D.C Western District of Tennessee, Civ. Action No.&nbsp;01-2582GV). The allegations in the </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><I>Sax</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2> case are substantially the same as those in the </FONT><FONT
SIZE=2><I>McCoy-Johnson</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2> and </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><I>Rodney</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2> cases. Northwest believes these cases to be without merit and intends to defend against the claims. The plaintiffs' motion for class
certification is pending. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Spirit Airlines v. Northwest Airlines</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2> (U.S. D.C. Eastern District of Michigan, Civ. Action
No.&nbsp;00-71535).&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In March&nbsp;2000, Spirit Airlines filed a Sherman Act monopolization complaint against Northwest in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District
of Michigan alleging that Northwest had monopolized, or attempted to monopolize, air transportation service between Detroit and Philadelphia and between Detroit and Boston in 1996 by engaging in
predatory pricing and other actions to exclude Spirit from those markets. Northwest believes the case to be without merit and intends to defend against the claim. On March&nbsp;31, 2003, the Court
granted Northwest's motion for summary judgment. Spirit's appeal of the Court's Order granting summary judgment is pending. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Force Majeure Arbitrations.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Each of Northwest's collective bargaining agreements with its unions contains "force majeure"
provisions, which provide that certain job protections, including layoff protections, are nullified in the event of a "force majeure". A "force majeure" is generally defined as the occurrence of
certain events over which Northwest does not have control. Northwest has invoked the "force majeure" provisions of its collective bargaining agreements in laying off employees in response to three
events: the terrorist attacks of September&nbsp;11, 2001, the outbreak of war in Iraq in March&nbsp;2003 and the SARS epidemic in 2003. Each of the IAM, International Brotherhood of Teamsters,
Chauffeurs, Warehousemen&nbsp;&amp; Helpers of America ("IBT") (which was recently decertified following a representation election in favor of the PFAA), ALPA and AMFA have filed one or more grievances
over the invocation of the force majeure provisions on some or all of these occasions. These disputes are subject to arbitration and are in various stages of the grievance/arbitration process </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>18</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=4,SEQ=18,EFW="2130102",CP="NORTHWEST AIRLINES CORPORATION",DN="1",CHK=950408,FOLIO='18',FILE='DISK016:[04STP4.04STP1114]DI1114A.;7',USER='TCHAN',CD=';4-MAR-2004;00:57' -->
<A NAME="page_di1114_1_19"> </A>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>provided
for in the respective collective bargaining agreements. An arbitrator has denied both the IBT/PFAA and AMFA grievances with respect to the Company's invocation of "force majeure" in
connection with the terrorist attacks of September&nbsp;11, 2001. An adverse decision in any of the remaining grievances could result in substantial damages against the Company. The Company is
vigorously defending these grievances. Although the ultimate outcome of these matters cannot be predicted with certainty, management believes it properly applied the terms of the various collective
bargaining agreements and that the resolution of these matters will not have a material adverse effect on the Company's consolidated financial statements taken as a whole. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Series&nbsp;C Preferred Stock Litigation.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In June&nbsp;2003, the IBT and certain related parties commenced litigation
against Northwest Airlines Corporation in New York state court, </FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>International Brotherhood of Teamsters, Local 2000 et al. v. Northwest Airlines
Corporation</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2> (New York Sup. Ct., Case No.&nbsp;601742/03). In August&nbsp;2003, the IAM and a related party also commenced litigation against Northwest Airlines Corporation
in New York state court, </FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers et al. v. Northwest Airlines Corporation</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2> (New York Sup. Ct., Case
No.&nbsp;602476/03). Both lawsuits challenge the Company's decision not to purchase its Series&nbsp;C Preferred Stock during 2003 and seek to compel the Company to repurchase the Series&nbsp;C
Preferred Stock that had been put to the Company. The Company announced on August&nbsp;1, 2003, that the Board of Directors had determined that the Company could not legally repurchase the
outstanding Series&nbsp;C Preferred Stock at that time because the Board was unable to determine that the Company had adequate surplus to repurchase the outstanding Series&nbsp;C Preferred Stock.
The Company believes that the lawsuits are without merit. Discovery has commenced. A court decision that adequate statutory surplus is available for a stock repurchase at this time could result in the
Company having to repurchase without deferral the outstanding Series&nbsp;C Preferred Stock (approximately $236&nbsp;million as of December&nbsp;31, 2003). </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
addition, in the ordinary course of its business, the Company is party to various other legal actions which the Company believes are incidental to the operation of its business. The
Company believes that the outcome of the proceedings to which it is currently a party (including those described above) will not have a material adverse effect on the Company's consolidated financial
statements taken as a whole. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Item 4. SUBMISSION OF MATTERS TO A VOTE OF SECURITY HOLDERS  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;No matters were submitted to a vote of the Company's security holders during the fourth quarter of 2003. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>MANAGEMENT  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Executive Officers of the Registrant  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B>Richard H. Anderson</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>, age 48, has served as Chief Executive Officer of NWA Corp. and Northwest since
April&nbsp;2001 and was elected a director of both companies in September&nbsp;2001. He has served in a number of executive positions since joining Northwest in 1990, including Executive Vice
President and Chief Operating Officer from December&nbsp;1998 to April&nbsp;2001, Executive Vice President-Technical Operations and Airport Affairs from April&nbsp;1998 to December&nbsp;1998
and Senior Vice President-Technical Operations and Airport Affairs from January&nbsp;1997 to April&nbsp;1998. From 1994 to 1996, he served as Senior Vice President-Labor Relations, State Affairs
and Law, and from 1990 to 1994 he served as Vice President-Deputy General Counsel. Prior to joining Northwest, Mr.&nbsp;Anderson was Staff Vice President and Deputy General Counsel of Continental
Airlines. Mr.&nbsp;Anderson serves on the board of directors of Medtronic,&nbsp;Inc. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT><FONT
SIZE=2><B>Douglas M. Steenland</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>, age 52, has served as President of NWA Corp. and Northwest since April&nbsp;2001 and was elected a director of
both companies in September&nbsp;2001. He has served in a number of executive positions since joining Northwest in 1991, including Executive Vice President and </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>19</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=5,SEQ=19,EFW="2130102",CP="NORTHWEST AIRLINES CORPORATION",DN="1",CHK=839579,FOLIO='19',FILE='DISK016:[04STP4.04STP1114]DI1114A.;7',USER='TCHAN',CD=';4-MAR-2004;00:57' -->
<A NAME="page_di1114_1_20"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Chief
Corporate Officer from September&nbsp;1999 to April&nbsp;2001, Executive Vice President-Alliances, General Counsel and Secretary from January&nbsp;1999 to September&nbsp;1999, Executive
Vice President, General Counsel and Secretary from June&nbsp;1998 to January&nbsp;1999, and Senior Vice President, General Counsel and Secretary from July&nbsp;1994 to June&nbsp;1998. Prior to
joining Northwest, Mr.&nbsp;Steenland was a senior partner at the Washington, D.C. law firm of Verner, Liipfert, Bernhard, McPherson and Hand. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT><FONT
SIZE=2><B>Bernard L. Han</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>, age 39, has served as Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer of the Company since October&nbsp;2002. Prior
to rejoining the Company, Mr.&nbsp;Han served at America West
Airlines,&nbsp;Inc. as Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer from September&nbsp;2001 to October&nbsp;2002, Senior Vice President&#151;Marketing and Planning from
May&nbsp;1998 to September&nbsp;2001 and Vice President Financial Planning&nbsp;&amp; Analysis from January&nbsp;1996 to May&nbsp;1998. Between 1988 and 1995, Mr.&nbsp;Han held various finance
and marketing positions at American Airlines and Northwest Airlines. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT><FONT
SIZE=2><B>J. Timothy Griffin</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>, age 52, has served as Executive Vice President-Marketing and Distribution of Northwest since January&nbsp;1999. From
June&nbsp;1993 to January&nbsp;1999, he served as Senior Vice President-Market Planning and Systems. Prior to joining Northwest in 1993, Mr.&nbsp;Griffin held senior positions with Continental
Airlines and American Airlines. Mr.&nbsp;Griffin also serves on the board of directors of Pinnacle Airlines Corp. and Orbitz,&nbsp;Inc. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT><FONT
SIZE=2><B>Philip C. Haan</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>, age 48, has served as Executive Vice President-International, Sales and Information Services of Northwest since
January&nbsp;1999. From December&nbsp;1995 to January&nbsp;1999, he served as Senior Vice President-International Services. Mr.&nbsp;Haan formerly held positions of Vice President-Pricing and
Area Marketing, Vice President-Inventory Sales and Systems and Vice President-Revenue Management. Prior to joining Northwest in 1991 he was with American Airlines for nine years. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As
of January&nbsp;30, 2004, there were 3,648 stockholders of record. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Since
1989, NWA Corp. has not declared or paid any dividends on its common stock and does not currently intend to do so. Under the provisions of certain of the Company's bank credit
agreements, NWA Corp.'s ability to pay dividends on or repurchase its common stock is restricted. Any future determination to pay cash dividends will be at the discretion of the Board of Directors,
subject to applicable limitations under Delaware law, and will be dependent upon the Company's results of operations, financial condition, contractual restrictions and other factors deemed relevant by
the Board of Directors. </FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE ALIGN="LEFT" WIDTH="120">
<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>(1)</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>2001
was affected by significantly reduced demand for travel resulting from the September&nbsp;11, 2001 terrorist attacks. The Company recognized $461&nbsp;million of grant income
from the U.S. Government under the Air Transportation Safety and System Stabilization Act, which was recorded as other non-operating income.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>(2)</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>All
statistics exclude Pinnacle Airlines, consistent with how the Company reports statistics to the DOT, and is comparable to statistics reported by other major network airlines.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>(3)</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>These
financial measures exclude non-passenger service revenues and expenses. The Company believes that by providing financial measures directly related to passenger
service operations, investors are able to evaluate and compare the Company's core operating results to those of the industry. </FONT></DD></DL>
<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>22</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=2,SEQ=22,EFW="2130102",CP="NORTHWEST AIRLINES CORPORATION",DN="1",CHK=36311,FOLIO='22',FILE='DISK016:[04STP4.04STP1114]DK1114A.;15',USER='ESCHAEF',CD=';4-MAR-2004;14:50' -->
<A NAME="page_dk1114_1_23"> </A>
<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>(4)</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Pursuant
to SEC Regulation&nbsp;S-K, Item&nbsp;10(e), a reconciliation of passenger service operating expenses to total operating expenses is provided below: </FONT></DD></DL>
<BR>

<TH WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=1>&nbsp;</FONT></TH>
<TH COLSPAN=14 ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=1><B>(In&nbsp;millions)<BR> </B></FONT><BR></TH>
</TR>
<TR BGCOLOR="#CCEEFF" VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<TD COLSPAN=2><FONT SIZE=2>Passenger service operating expenses(a)</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=2>$</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="7%" ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2>8,800</FONT></TD>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>23</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=3,SEQ=23,EFW="2130102",CP="NORTHWEST AIRLINES CORPORATION",DN="1",CHK=444807,FOLIO='23',FILE='DISK016:[04STP4.04STP1114]DK1114A.;15',USER='ESCHAEF',CD=';4-MAR-2004;14:50' -->
<!-- THIS IS THE END OF A COMPOSITION COMPONENT -->

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="page_dm1114_1_24"> </A> </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><B>Item&nbsp;7. MANAGEMENT'S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Overview  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;NWA Corp. is a holding company whose principal indirect operating subsidiary is Northwest. The Consolidated Financial Statements include the accounts of NWA Corp.
and all consolidated subsidiaries. Substantially all of the Company's results of operations are attributable to its principal indirect operating subsidiary, Northwest, which accounted for
approximately 98% of the Company's 2003 consolidated operating revenues and expenses. The Company's results of operations also include other subsidiaries, of which MLT and Pinnacle Airlines have been
the most significant. The following discussion pertains primarily to Northwest and, where indicated, MLT and Pinnacle Airlines. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
Company reported net income of $236&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2003, compared with a net loss of $798&nbsp;million in 2002. Diluted earnings per share
were $2.74 in 2003 compared with a loss per share of $9.32 in 2002. Operating loss was $265&nbsp;million in 2003 compared with an operating loss of $846&nbsp;million in 2002. Passenger revenues
for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2003 decreased by $89&nbsp;million compared to 2002, continuing their three year trend of decline. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Full
year 2003 results included $801&nbsp;million of net unusual pre-tax gains. Operating expenses included $99&nbsp;million of unusual items related to employee
severance, a pension curtailment charge and aircraft write-downs. Net unusual non-operating gains totaling $900&nbsp;million were comprised of a $299&nbsp;million gain from the initial
public offering of 88.6% of the Company's investment in Pinnacle Airlines Corp., $209&nbsp;million received under the Emergency Wartime Supplemental Appropriations Act as reimbursement for security
fees previously paid to the TSA, a $199&nbsp;million gain from the sale of the Company's investment in WorldSpan, a $148&nbsp;million net gain related to the acquisition of the corporation which
held the Company's Mandatorily Redeemable Preferred Security, a $39&nbsp;million gain from the sale of its investment in Hotwire.com ("Hotwire"), an $11&nbsp;million gain from the sale of a
portion of its investment in Orbitz and a $5&nbsp;million loss on the Company's debt exchange. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Full
year 2002 results included $464&nbsp;million in unusual pre-tax charges, principally comprised of $352&nbsp;million attributable to the accelerated retirement of
certain Boeing&nbsp;747-200 and DC10-30 aircraft, $53&nbsp;million of costs associated with the closure of several facilities, $32&nbsp;million related to employee
benefit costs and additional asset write-downs, and a $27&nbsp;million partial write-down of the Company's receivable from the U.S. Government related to the grant under the Airline
Stabilization Act. In addition, the 2002 effective tax rate reflected a $15&nbsp;million provision for tax credits the Company expected to expire unused. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Northwest and the Current Status of the Airline Industry  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The airline industry is intensely competitive. Northwest's competitors include other major domestic airlines as well as foreign, regional and new entrant
airlines, some of which have more financial resources or lower cost structures than Northwest. In most markets that Northwest serves, it competes with at least one of these carriers. Our revenues are
sensitive to numerous factors, and the actions of other carriers in the areas of pricing, scheduling and promotions can have a substantial adverse impact on overall industry revenues. Such factors may
become even more significant in periods when the industry experiences large losses, as airlines under financial stress, or in bankruptcy, may institute pricing structures intended to achieve near term
survival rather than long term viability. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Since
2001, the U.S. airline industry overall has suffered a substantial reduction in revenues, both on an absolute basis and relative to historical trends. The Company's annual
operating revenue has declined in each of the last three years and its 2003 operating revenue was over $1.7&nbsp;billion less than it was in 2000. As a result, the Company has incurred significant
operating losses, and absent unusual items, its pre-tax losses over that period have totaled nearly $2.2&nbsp;billion. The Company does not </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>24</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=1,SEQ=24,EFW="2130102",CP="NORTHWEST AIRLINES CORPORATION",DN="1",CHK=688832,FOLIO='24',FILE='DISK016:[04STP4.04STP1114]DM1114A.;14',USER='JPATROW',CD=';3-MAR-2004;20:36' -->
<A NAME="page_dm1114_1_25"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>anticipate
that the revenue environment will materially improve in 2004. Due to the discretionary nature of business and personal travel spending, U.S. airline revenues are heavily influenced by the
strength of the U.S. economy, other regional world economies and corporate profitability. The revenue decline has been due in part to the U.S. economic cycle. However, permanent structural differences
in the industry revenue environment have also taken place. These differences are the result of a number of factors. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
rapid growth of low cost airlines has had a profound impact on industry revenues. Using the advantage of low unit costs, driven in large part by lower labor costs, these carriers are
able to operate profitably while offering substantially lower fares. By targeting such fares at business passengers in particular, these carriers are shifting demand away from the larger, more
established airlines. These low cost carriers now transport more than 25% of all domestic U.S. passengers, compared to less than 10% a decade ago. They now compete for, and thus influence industry
pricing on, approximately 75% of all domestic U.S. passenger ticket sales, versus less than 20% a decade ago. Moreover, as a result of their better financial performance, low cost carriers have the
resources necessary to continue to increase their market share. Industry revenue could be reduced substantially in the event one or more large
network carriers decides it is a better long-term strategy to adopt a broad pricing structure similar to those employed by low cost carriers rather than give up additional market share. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Internet
travel Web sites have driven significant distribution cost savings for airlines, but have also allowed consumers to become more efficient at finding lower fare alternatives than
in the past by providing them with more powerful pricing information. The increased price consciousness of both business and leisure travelers, as well as the growth in new distribution channels, has
further motivated airlines to price aggressively to gain fare and market share advantages. These factors will increase over time as Internet ticket sales increase. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Airlines
are among the most heavily taxed of all U.S. companies. Taxes and fees can add up to approximately 25% of what a passenger pays for an average roundtrip domestic airline ticket,
a percentage even greater than that for alcohol and tobacco products. These taxes and fees have grown significantly in the past decade. The Company believes that every dollar of tax or fee increase
imposed on airline passengers roughly translates into a dollar of reduced airline revenue. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
attacks of September&nbsp;11, 2001 materially impacted air travel and, with concerns about further terrorist attacks unlikely to abate any time soon, continue to have a negative
effect on travel demand. Additionally, security procedures introduced at airports since the attacks have increased the inconvenience of flying, both in reality and in perception, and thus have further
reduced demand. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Global
events further exacerbated the decline in airline industry revenue in 2003. The war in Iraq and its aftermath and the outbreak of Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome ("SARS") have
materially affected airline bookings and continue to negatively impact air travel, particularly on international routes. Another outbreak of SARS or other influenza-type illness, if it
were to persist for an extended period, could materially affect the airline industry by reducing revenues and impacting travel behavior, especially on routes to and from certain Asian destinations. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
response to the industry environment, the Company has taken aggressive steps to mitigate the impact on its results of operations and financial condition resulting from these adverse
trends. In the past two years, these steps have included a significant decrease in scheduled capacity on an available seat mile basis, a reduction in work force of over 16,900 full time equivalent
positions, deferral of certain aircraft orders, closure of maintenance facilities, flight crew bases, reservations and sales facilities and deferrals and cancellations of discretionary and other
non-operationally critical spending. In all, eight rounds of cost savings have been initiated since the U.S. economy began weakening in early 2001, resulting in cost reductions totaling
$1.6&nbsp;billion. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>25</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=2,SEQ=25,EFW="2130102",CP="NORTHWEST AIRLINES CORPORATION",DN="1",CHK=633846,FOLIO='25',FILE='DISK016:[04STP4.04STP1114]DM1114A.;14',USER='JPATROW',CD=';3-MAR-2004;20:36' -->
<A NAME="page_dm1114_1_26"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Despite
these and other significant steps to reduce costs, additional measures will be necessary in response to the fundamentally changed industry revenue environment. Wages, salaries
and benefits made up 40% of the Company's 2003 operating expenses and will be the critical component of future cost reduction initiatives. The Company is in discussions with its labor unions in an
effort to align wages, benefits and work rules with the new revenue environment and to remain competitive with airlines that have achieved permanent labor cost reductions through bankruptcy
proceedings (United Airlines, US Airways) or the threat of bankruptcy (American Airlines). The Company cannot predict the outcome of these negotiations at this time. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Results of Operations&#151;2003 Compared to 2002  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Operating Revenues.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Operating revenues increased 0.2% ($21&nbsp;million). System passenger revenues decreased 1.6%
($124&nbsp;million), excluding Pinnacle Airlines. The decrease in system passenger revenues was primarily attributable to a 4.9% decrease in traffic partially offset by a 3.5% increase in yields.
Pinnacle Airlines passenger revenues, net of intercompany eliminations, increased 13.3% ($36&nbsp;million) to $307&nbsp;million due to increased capacity from 25 Bombardier CRJ aircraft added in
2003. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The

<!-- end of user-specified TAGGED TABLE -->

<UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Domestic
passenger revenues increased primarily due to slight improvements in yields, partially offset by a small decline in traffic.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Pacific
passenger revenues decreased substantially due to lower traffic. Despite a 6.1% reduction in capacity, largely intended to match lower demand as a result of the Iraq
War and the SARS epidemic, the Pacific load factor was down 2.5&nbsp;percentage points.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Atlantic
passenger revenues decreased due to a significant reduction in traffic caused by the Iraq War, some of which was offset by higher yields. </FONT></DD></DL>
</UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Cargo
revenues increased 2.3% ($17&nbsp;million) to $752&nbsp;million due to a 4.1% increase in yield, partially offset by a 1.7% decline in cargo ton miles. Cargo revenues consist
of freight and mail carried on passenger aircraft and the Company's 12 Boeing 747-200F dedicated freighters. Freight revenue increased 5.2% ($34&nbsp;million) while mail revenue
decreased 22.8% ($17&nbsp;million). In the last half of 2003, the Company decided to stop carrying U.S. domestic mail as lower volumes and yields, partially due to restrictions imposed by the U.S.
Government following September&nbsp;11, 2001, caused this business to become unprofitable. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Other
revenues, the principal components of which are MLT, other transportation fees and charter revenues, increased 12.8% ($93&nbsp;million). This increase was primarily due to
increased revenues from CRAF and other charter activities, frequent flyer partnership revenue, ticketing and handling fees, KLM joint venture settlements, the NBA transportation program and support
services revenue. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>26</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>

<A NAME="page_dm1114_1_27"> </A>
<BR>

for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2003 and describes significant variances from the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2002: </FONT></P>

<!-- end of user-specified TAGGED TABLE -->

<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>A.</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Salaries,
wages and benefits increased due to higher pension expenses, including a $58&nbsp;million pension curtailment charge, annual pay rate increases, $20&nbsp;million of
severance expenses, and contractually required payments to employees represented by the International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers and the Transportation Communications Union,
partially offset by savings from an 11.8% decrease in average full-time equivalent employees.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>B.</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Aircraft
fuel and taxes were higher due to a 16.4% increase in the average fuel cost per gallon to 80.68&nbsp;cents, net of hedging transactions, partially offset by 7.6% fewer fuel
gallons consumed as a result of reduced capacity and the use of more fuel efficient aircraft. Fuel hedge transactions reduced fuel costs by $105&nbsp;million in 2003 and $55&nbsp;million in 2002.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>C.</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Selling
and marketing expenses decreased $94&nbsp;million, due primarily to the elimination of North American base travel agency commissions, which began to take effect near the end
of the second quarter of 2002, lower passenger volumes and lower advertising expenses.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>D.</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Depreciation
and amortization decreased primarily due to $372&nbsp;million of aircraft and related parts write-downs recorded in 2002, offset slightly by similar charges of
$21&nbsp;million recorded in the second quarter of 2003.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>E.</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Other
rentals and landing fees remained relatively unchanged. Generally higher rates system wide were offset by lower volume.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>F.</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Aircraft
rentals increased due to additional leased aircraft, partially offset by lower variable interest rates on existing leases.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>G.</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Aircraft
maintenance materials and repairs decreased by $102&nbsp;million, due primarily to lower material usage from reduced maintenance volume, which resulted from lower fleet
utilization and a significant number of new aircraft in the fleet.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>H.</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Other
expenses (which include MLT operating expenses, outside services, insurance, passenger food, personnel expenses, communication expenses and supplies) decreased principally due to
lower Northwest passenger volumes, lower passenger liability insurance and lower MLT operating expenses. </FONT></DD></DL>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Other Income and Expense.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Other non-operating income increased by $857&nbsp;million, primarily due to several
unusual items: a $299&nbsp;million gain from the sale of the Company's investment in Pinnacle Airlines Corp.; $209&nbsp;million received under the Emergency Wartime Supplemental Appropriations Act </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>27</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=4,SEQ=27,EFW="2130102",CP="NORTHWEST AIRLINES CORPORATION",DN="1",CHK=417999,FOLIO='27',FILE='DISK016:[04STP4.04STP1114]DM1114A.;14',USER='JPATROW',CD=';3-MAR-2004;20:36' -->
<A NAME="page_dm1114_1_28"> </A>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>as
reimbursement for security fees previously paid to the TSA; a $199&nbsp;million gain from the sale of the Company's investment in WorldSpan; a $361&nbsp;million gain related to a
write-down of the Company's Mandatorily Redeemable Preferred Security, accompanied by an impairment charge of $213&nbsp;million related to the property securing this obligation; a
$39&nbsp;million gain from the sale of the Company's investment in Hotwire; and an $11&nbsp;million gain from the sale of a portion of the Company's investment in Orbitz. The Company also
generated a higher return on short-term investments, which partially offset higher interest expense related to increased debt levels. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Tax Expense (Benefit).</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During 2003, the Company recognized a $30&nbsp;million tax benefit related to losses recorded in the
first quarter that fully offset its remaining $30&nbsp;million net deferred tax liability. Given recent loss experience, current accounting rules do not allow the Company's balance sheet to reflect
a net deferred tax asset. Therefore, a valuation allowance is provided against tax benefits, principally for net operating losses in excess of its previously remaining deferred tax liability. See
"Item&nbsp;8. Consolidated Financial Statements and Supplementary Data, Note&nbsp;9&#151;Income Taxes", for additional discussion of the Company's tax accounts. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Results of Operations&#151;2002 Compared to 2001  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Operating Revenues.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Operating revenues decreased 4.2% ($416&nbsp;million). System passenger revenues decreased 5.7%
($466&nbsp;million), excluding Pinnacle Airlines. The decrease in system passenger revenues was primarily attributable to a 1.5% decrease in traffic and a 4.3% decline in yields. System passenger
load factor increased 2.8 points to 77.1% for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2002. Pinnacle Airlines passenger revenues, net of intercompany eliminations, increased 36.9% ($73&nbsp;million) to
$271&nbsp;million due to increased capacity from 21 Bombardier CRJ aircraft added in 2002 and higher rates under a new airline services agreement with Northwest that was effective March&nbsp;1,
2002. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
following analysis by market is based on information reported to the DOT and excludes Pinnacle Airlines: </FONT></P>

<!-- end of user-specified TAGGED TABLE -->

<UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Domestic
passenger revenues decreased primarily due to a combination of lower yields and traffic.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Pacific
passenger revenues decreased due to lower yields. Traffic was virtually unchanged, resulting in a higher passenger load factor on decreased capacity.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Atlantic
passenger revenues were effectively flat, as slightly improved yields were mostly offset by a small reduction in traffic. </FONT></DD></DL>
</UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Cargo
revenues increased 2.1% ($15&nbsp;million) to $735&nbsp;million due to a 2.8% increase in cargo ton miles partially offset by a 0.6% decline in revenue per ton mile. Cargo
revenues consist of freight and mail carried on passenger aircraft and the Company's 12 747-200F dedicated freighters. Freight revenue increased 7.4% ($46&nbsp;million), including
approximately $27&nbsp;million in the fourth quarter resulting from </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>28</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=5,SEQ=28,EFW="2130102",CP="NORTHWEST AIRLINES CORPORATION",DN="1",CHK=207425,FOLIO='28',FILE='DISK016:[04STP4.04STP1114]DM1114A.;14',USER='JPATROW',CD=';3-MAR-2004;20:36' -->
<A NAME="page_dm1114_1_29"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>the
west coast dockworkers' lockout. However, this was partially offset by a 29.6% ($31&nbsp;million) decrease in mail revenue, due largely to lower volumes resulting from U.S. Government
restrictions imposed following September&nbsp;11, 2001 on the transportation of packages larger than 16 ounces on passenger aircraft. Such restrictions were responsible, in part, for Northwest
ultimately deciding in the second half of 2003 to discontinue U.S. domestic mail carriage as lower volumes and yields caused this business to become unprofitable. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Other
revenues, the principal components of which are MLT, other transportation fees and charter revenues, decreased 5.1% ($39&nbsp;million). This decline was primarily due to reduced
revenues from MLT, KLM joint venture settlements, ticketing and handling fees and support services, partially offset by an increase in frequent flyer program partnership revenue. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Operating Expenses.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Operating expenses decreased 4.1% ($438&nbsp;million). The following table presents operating expenses
for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2002 and describes significant variances from the year ending December&nbsp;31, 2001: </FONT></P>

<!-- User-specified TAGGED TABLE -->
<TABLE WIDTH="93%" BORDER=0 CELLSPACING=0 CELLPADDING=0>
<TR VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<TH COLSPAN=2 ALIGN="LEFT"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT><BR></TH>
<TH WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=1>&nbsp;</FONT></TH>
<TH COLSPAN=2 ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=1><B>Year ended<BR>
December&nbsp;31, 2002</B></FONT><HR NOSHADE></TH>
<TH WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=1>&nbsp;</FONT></TH>
<TH COLSPAN=2 ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=1><B>Increase<BR>
(Decrease)<BR>
from 2001</B></FONT><HR NOSHADE></TH>
<TH WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=1>&nbsp;</FONT></TH>
<TH WIDTH="8%" ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=1><B>Percent<BR>
Change</B></FONT><HR NOSHADE></TH>
<TH WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=1>&nbsp;</FONT></TH>

<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>A.</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Salaries,
wages and benefits decreased primarily due to 10.6% fewer full-time equivalent employees and $89&nbsp;million for retroactive wages and benefits related to the
2001 AMFA collective bargaining agreement. This decline was partially offset by higher average wage rates, pension, group insurance, and other post employment benefit expenses. Pension expenses
increased largely due to a lower actuarial discount rate, a decline in pension asset returns and increased benefits from the 2001 AMFA contract.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>B.</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Aircraft
fuel and taxes were lower due to a 12.5% decrease in the average fuel cost per gallon to 69.33&nbsp;cents, net of hedging transactions, and 6.6% fewer fuel gallons consumed
as a result of reduced capacity and the use of more fuel efficient aircraft. Fuel hedge transactions reduced fuel costs by $55&nbsp;million in 2002 and had an immaterial effect in 2001.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>C.</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Depreciation
and amortization increased primarily due to $372&nbsp;million of aircraft and related parts write-downs recorded in 2002, offset by similar charges of
$161&nbsp;million recorded in the third and fourth quarters of 2001. The increase in depreciation and amortization was partially offset by the elimination of $24&nbsp;million per year from
international route and goodwill amortization recorded prior to 2002. See "Item&nbsp;8. Consolidated Financial Statements and Supplementary Data, Note&nbsp;1&#151;Summary of Significant
Accounting Policies", for additional discussion of the fleet disposition charges and international routes and goodwill no longer being amortized.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>D.</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Selling
and marketing decreased $109&nbsp;million due primarily to the elimination of North American base commissions in the second quarter of 2002 and $40&nbsp;million due to
lower revenues system-wide. </FONT></DD></DL>
<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>29</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=6,SEQ=29,EFW="2130102",CP="NORTHWEST AIRLINES CORPORATION",DN="1",CHK=346607,FOLIO='29',FILE='DISK016:[04STP4.04STP1114]DM1114A.;14',USER='JPATROW',CD=';3-MAR-2004;20:36' -->
<A NAME="page_dm1114_1_30"> </A>
<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>E.</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Aircraft
maintenance materials and repairs decreased due to lower repair volume in 2002, which resulted from retirements and removal from service of older aircraft, as well as a higher
level of scheduled work within the routine engine and airframe maintenance cycle in 2001.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>F.</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Other
rentals and landing fees increased primarily due to the new Detroit Midfield facility, as well as higher rates across the system due to unfunded TSA mandates.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>G.</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Aircraft
rentals increased due to additional leased aircraft, partially offset by lower variable interest rates on existing leases.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>H.</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Other
expenses (the principal components of which include MLT operating expenses, outside services, insurance, passenger food, personnel expenses, communication expenses and supplies)
decreased principally due to lower personnel, supplies and claims expenses and reduced levels of passenger food service, partially offset by significantly higher insurance costs. </FONT></DD></DL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Other Income and Expense.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Other non-operating income decreased by $572&nbsp;million, primarily due to
$461&nbsp;million recognized in 2001 under the Airline Stabilization Act, higher 2002 interest expense related to increased debt levels, and lower interest income as a result of lower interest
rates. In the fourth quarter of 2002, the Company recorded a $27&nbsp;million charge to write-down a portion of a receivable from the U.S. Government to reflect the final amount received
in January&nbsp;2003 under the Airline Stabilization Act. Interest expense increased 15.7% ($58&nbsp;million) primarily due to the full year 2002 borrowings under the Company's revolving credit
facilities and additional new financings. Higher earnings from affiliates during 2002 were partially offset by a $27&nbsp;million gain from the sale of the Company's remaining shares of Continental
recorded in 2001. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Tax Expense (Benefit).</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The tax benefit recorded in 2002 includes a provision of $15&nbsp;million for tax credits that are
expected to expire unused. The Company's net deferred tax liability declined from $843&nbsp;million
at December&nbsp;31, 2001 to $30&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31, 2002, primarily due to the increase in deferred tax assets relating to the Company's pension plans and the Company's 2002
losses. Given the Company's recent loss experience, current accounting rules do not allow its balance sheet to reflect a net tax asset position. As a result, when losses after December&nbsp;31, 2002
generated deferred tax assets that fully offset the Company's then existing deferred tax liabilities, no tax benefit could be recognized with respect to further losses. See "Item&nbsp;8.
Consolidated Financial Statements and Supplementary Data, Note&nbsp;9&#151;Income Taxes", for additional discussion of the Company's tax accounts. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Liquidity and Capital Resources  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As of December&nbsp;31, 2003, the Company had cash, cash equivalents and short-term investments of $2.883&nbsp;billion. This amount included
$126&nbsp;million of restricted short-term investments, resulting in total unrestricted liquidity of $2.757&nbsp;billion. As discussed later, the Company's secured credit facilities
were fully drawn as of December&nbsp;31, 2002 and had approximately $1&nbsp;million available as of December&nbsp;31, 2003. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Cash Flows.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Liquidity increased by $660&nbsp;million as of December&nbsp;31, 2003, due primarily to $209&nbsp;million
security fee reimbursements received from the U.S. Government under the Emergency Wartime Supplemental Appropriations Act, a $218&nbsp;million income tax refund, cash proceeds of $278&nbsp;million
from the sale of WorldSpan and the issuances of $150&nbsp;million and $225&nbsp;million of senior convertible notes, partially offset by $158&nbsp;million in cash contributions to the pension
plans, capital expenditures, net of financings, and other investing and financing activities. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Operating Activities.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Cash provided by operating activities was $375&nbsp;million in 2003 compared to cash used by
operating activities of $284&nbsp;million in 2002. This increase of $659&nbsp;million was largely due to the $209&nbsp;million of Emergency Wartime Supplemental Appropriations Act funds received
in May&nbsp;2003, net income tax receipts $93&nbsp;million higher in 2003 than 2002 and the payment in </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>30</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=7,SEQ=30,EFW="2130102",CP="NORTHWEST AIRLINES CORPORATION",DN="1",CHK=164233,FOLIO='30',FILE='DISK016:[04STP4.04STP1114]DM1114A.;14',USER='JPATROW',CD=';3-MAR-2004;20:36' -->
<!-- THIS IS THE END OF A COMPOSITION COMPONENT -->

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="page_do1114_1_31"> </A> </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2>
January&nbsp;2002 of $216&nbsp;million of aviation taxes originally due between September&nbsp;11, 2001 and January&nbsp;15, 2002. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
Company operates, like its competitors, with negative working capital, which totaled $297&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31, 2003. This negative working capital position is
primarily attributable to the Company's $1.27&nbsp;billion air traffic liability, largely representing cash received from tickets that customers have not yet used. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Investing Activities.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Investing activities consist primarily of the purchase of short-term investments, aircraft
capital expenditures and other related costs. Other related costs include engine purchases, costs to commission aircraft before entering revenue service, deposits on ordered aircraft, facility
improvements and ground equipment purchases. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Investing
activities related to the acquisitions of aircraft consisted of the following for years ended December&nbsp;31: </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Investing
activities in 2003, other than aircraft purchases and short-term investments, include proceeds of $278&nbsp;million from the sale of the Company's interest in
WorldSpan, $255&nbsp;million from the sale of 88.6% of the Company's interest in Pinnacle Airlines Corp., $40&nbsp;million from the sale of the Company's interest in Hotwire and $13&nbsp;million
from the sale of a portion of its investment in Orbitz. Investing activities in 2002, other than aircraft purchases, include facilities and aircraft modification programs. Investing activities in
2001, other than aircraft purchases, include $582&nbsp;million in proceeds from the sale of the Company's investment in Continental. See "Item 8. Consolidated Financial Statements and Supplementary
Data, Note&nbsp;13&#151;Related Party Transactions", for additional discussion of the Company's investment in Continental. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Financing Activities.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Financing activities in 2003 consist primarily of the issuance of $150&nbsp;million of 6.625%
convertible senior notes due in 2023, the issuance of $225&nbsp;million of 7.625% convertible senior notes due in 2023, the payment of debt and capital lease obligations, and the financing of:
(i)&nbsp;11 Airbus A319, four Boeing 757-300 and three Airbus A330-300 aircraft with escrowed funds from an offering of pass-through trust certificates completed
in 2002; and (ii)&nbsp;two Boeing 757-300, one Airbus A330-300, one Airbus A320 and one Airbus A319 aircraft with long-term debt. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
addition to the financed aircraft discussed above, the Company also took delivery of one Airbus A330-300, one Airbus A320, one Airbus A319, three Boeing
757-300 aircraft and 25 Bombardier CRJ200/440 regional jets during the twelve months ended December&nbsp;31, 2003. The Airbus A300-300, A320 and A319 aircraft and the three
Boeing 757-300 aircraft were acquired through non-cash transactions with manufacturers. The Bombardier CRJ aircraft were acquired and financed with long-term
operating leases and subleased to Pinnacle Airlines. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On
December&nbsp;9, 2003, Northwest completed an offer to exchange outstanding unsecured notes ("Old Notes") due in 2004, 2005 and 2006, with interest rates ranging from 7.625% to
8.875%, for new 10.5% class&nbsp;D pass-through trust certificates ("Class&nbsp;D Certificates") representing a fractional undivided interest in the assets of a
pass-through trust. The trust's assets consist of interests in </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>31</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=1,SEQ=31,EFW="2130102",CP="NORTHWEST AIRLINES CORPORATION",DN="1",CHK=8039,FOLIO='31',FILE='DISK016:[04STP4.04STP1114]DO1114A.;8',USER='JPATROW',CD=';3-MAR-2004;20:36' -->
<A NAME="page_do1114_1_32"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>$551.8&nbsp;million
principal amount of notes primarily secured by aircraft financed under five series of Northwest pass-through certificates previously issued. Holders tendered
approximately $59&nbsp;million of Old Notes for $64&nbsp;million of Class&nbsp;D Certificates. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
exchange was accounted for as an extinguishment of debt under generally accepted accounting principles, with the Company recording an associated loss because the cash flows of the
new debt instrument are greater than 110&nbsp;percent of the original instruments' remaining cash flows. The loss recognized in the Consolidated Statements of Operations due to this exchange offer
approximated $5&nbsp;million. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During
2003, NWA Corp. completed two offerings of $375&nbsp;million aggregate principle amount of convertible senior notes, both due in 2023. These notes were issued to qualified
institutional buyers pursuant to Rule&nbsp;144A and to non-U.S. persons pursuant to Regulation&nbsp;S, under the Securities Act of 1933. The first issuance of notes in May was for an
aggregate principal amount of $150&nbsp;million and bears interest at 6.625% (the "6.625% Notes"), which is payable in cash semi-annually through May&nbsp;15, 2010. Thereafter, the
principal amount of the notes will accrete semi-annually at a rate of 6.625% per year to maturity. The second issuance of notes in November was for an aggregate principal amount of
$225&nbsp;million and bears interest at 7.625% (the "7.625% Notes"), which is payable in cash semi-annually through November&nbsp;15, 2008. Thereafter, the principal amount of the
notes will accrete semi-annually at a rate of 7.625% per year to maturity. Each note was issued at a price of $1,000 and is convertible into NWA Corp. common stock. The 6.625% Notes and
the 7.625% Notes were issued with conversion rates of 61.8047 and 43.6681 shares per $1,000 original principal amount of notes, respectively. These conversion rates equate to an initial conversion
price of approximately $16.18 and $22.90 per share for the 6.625% Notes and the 7.625% Notes, respectively, subject to adjustment in certain circumstances. Both issuances of notes are guaranteed by
Northwest. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Holders
of the notes may convert their notes only if: (i)&nbsp;NWA Corp.'s common stock trades above a specified price threshold for a specified period; (ii)&nbsp;the trading price
for the notes falls below certain thresholds; (iii)&nbsp;the notes have been called for redemption; or (iv)&nbsp;specific corporate transactions occur. NWA Corp. may elect to pay the repurchase
price in cash or in shares of common stock, or a combination of both, subject to certain conditions. Should holders elect to require NWA Corp. to redeem the notes on any of the repurchase dates, it is
the Company's present intention to satisfy the requirement in cash. NWA Corp. may redeem all or some of the notes for cash at any time on or after May&nbsp;15, 2010 for the 6.625% Notes and on or
after November&nbsp;15, 2006 for the 7.625% Notes, at a redemption price in each case equal to the accreted principal amount plus accrued and unpaid interest, if any, to the redemption date. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Holders
of the 6.625% Notes may require NWA Corp. to repurchase the notes on May&nbsp;15, 2010, 2013 and 2018 at a price equal to the accreted principal amount plus accrued and unpaid
interest, if any, on the repurchase date. Holders of the 7.625% Notes may require NWA Corp. to repurchase the notes on November&nbsp;15, 2008, 2013 and 2018 at a price equal to the accreted
principal amount plus accrued and unpaid interest, if any, on the repurchase date. In conjunction with the issuance of the 7.625% Notes, NWA Corp. entered into a call spread option transaction that
was designed to limit the Company's exposure to potential dilution from conversion of the 7.625% Notes in the event that the market price per share of NWA Corp.'s common stock at the time of exercise
is greater than the strike price of $22.90. This call spread option will be treated as an equity transaction under the Emerging Issues Task Force ("EITF") Issue No. 00-19, </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><I>Accounting for Derivative Financial Instruments
Indexed to, and Potentially Settled in, a Company's Own Stock</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>. NWA Corp. plans to use the net proceeds
from the offerings for working capital and general corporate purposes. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Financing
activities in 2002 consisted primarily of the issuance of $300&nbsp;million of 9.875% unsecured notes due in 2007, the payment of debt and capital lease obligations, and the
financing of: (i)&nbsp;18 Airbus A319, one Boeing 747-400, two Airbus A320 and three Boeing 757-300 aircraft with </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>32</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=2,SEQ=32,EFW="2130102",CP="NORTHWEST AIRLINES CORPORATION",DN="1",CHK=539179,FOLIO='32',FILE='DISK016:[04STP4.04STP1114]DO1114A.;8',USER='JPATROW',CD=';3-MAR-2004;20:36' -->
<A NAME="page_do1114_1_33"> </A>
<BR>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>escrowed
funds from offerings of pass-through trust certificates completed in 2001; (ii)&nbsp;two Boeing 757-300 aircraft with escrowed funds from an offering of
pass-through trust certificates completed in 2002; (iii)&nbsp;three Boeing 757-200, two Boeing 757-300 and six Airbus A319 aircraft with long-term
bank debt; (iv)&nbsp;one Boeing 747-400 aircraft under a sale and leaseback; and the refinancing of three Boeing 747-400 aircraft purchased off capital lease. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
August&nbsp;2002, Northwest completed an offering of $749&nbsp;million of pass-through trust certificates to finance or refinance the acquisition of 11 new Airbus
A319, six new Boeing 757-300 and three new Airbus A330-300 aircraft that were delivered between October&nbsp;2002 and December&nbsp;2003. The pre-funded portion
of cash proceeds from the offerings of certificates were invested and held in escrow with a depositary bank. Such funds were not assets or direct obligations of, or guaranteed by, Northwest and are
therefore not included in the Consolidated Financial Statements. As aircraft were delivered or refinanced, Northwest utilized the cash proceeds to finance the acquisition of these aircraft as secured
debt financing for ownership. As of December&nbsp;31, 2003, there were no unused offering proceeds held in escrow. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Financing
activities in 2001 consisted primarily of the Company's borrowing in March and subsequent repayment in May of $1.10&nbsp;billion under its revolving credit facilities, the
borrowing on September&nbsp;11, 2001, of $1.12&nbsp;billion under its revolving credit facilities, of which $150&nbsp;million was repaid in October&nbsp;2001 as scheduled, the issuance of
$300&nbsp;million of 8.875% unsecured notes due 2006, $120&nbsp;million received under airport facility revenue bonds and payment of debt and capital lease obligations. Financing activities also
included the receipt of $678&nbsp;million in financing for: (i)&nbsp;13 Airbus A319 aircraft, seven of which were financed with funds from pass-through trust
certificates and six with long-term bank debt; (ii)&nbsp;five Boeing 757-200 aircraft financed with long-term bank debt; and (iii)&nbsp;four Airbus A320
aircraft, three of which were financed with funds from pass-through trust certificates and one with long-term bank debt. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
June&nbsp;2001, the Company completed an offering of $581&nbsp;million of pass-through certificates at a blended fixed coupon rate of 7.18%. Proceeds from sales of the
certificates were used to finance the acquisition of 14 aircraft consisting of nine new Airbus A319 aircraft, three new Boeing 757-300 aircraft and two new Boeing 747-400
aircraft delivered between March and December&nbsp;2002. In July&nbsp;2001, the Company completed an offering of $396&nbsp;million of European pass-through certificates due in 2013
at a blended floating rate of three-month London Interbank Offered Rate ("LIBOR") plus 0.60% (1.77% as of December&nbsp;31, 2003) to finance the acquisition of nine new Airbus A319 aircraft and five
new Airbus A320 aircraft delivered between November&nbsp;2001 and July&nbsp;2002. </FONT></P>

lease payments, aircraft purchases and certain other obligations for the years ending December&nbsp;31: </FONT></P>

<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>(2)</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Amounts
represent principal payments only. See "Item 8. Consolidated Financial Statements and Supplementary Data, Note&nbsp;4&#151;Leases", for information related to

represent minimum lease payments with initial or remaining terms of more than one year and exclude related sublease rental income. See "Item 8. Consolidated Financial
